Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course helped to develop my knowledge and understanding of developing research projects. I feel equipped to engage in research projects as a primary experimenter. I also learned a great deal about primate ecology.

How to think critically as a scientist. Additionally, the professors include stories abut current practices or challenges in their field and in science in general -- they want to teach all students critical thinking and how to question scientific knowledge and think of their own questions, regardless of their background. Also, by being incredibly open about their own experience as researchers and professors I gained a sense of what it is actually like to work in academia, and how to navigate unspoken aspects of networking and finding opportunities.
I learned so much about what it means to be a scientist in this course. In past Yale science classes I have never been encouraged to truly think about what it means to carry out research.

I learned so much more than what you can capture from the course title. While we did cover many techniques field researchers use to study animal behavior (telemetry, actimetry, census/surveys, etc.), we discussed and analyzed every step that one must take before using them. By doing so, we covered the fundamentals of experimental design and scientific reasoning. While I thought I had a firm grasp on this subject, the way we discussed them shifted the way I read literature and consider experimental design. Through the readings and class discussions, we go into considerable depth regarding the Owl Monkey Project, the activity patterns and social behavior of owl monkeys themselves, and the fauna of the Humid Chaco region of Argentina.

Review of literature of behavioral ecology, how to design and form research proposals from the scientific roots up. Hypothesis vs predictions, research questions, methods, ethograms, ethics, bibliographic software

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that this course was really wonderful. I think the assignments were all useful in the culminating final assignment, and I thought the emphasis on student wellbeing and learning were really valuable.

The strengths are: fascinating content, and investigated and engaged professors. The weaknesses are that occasionally the course was disorganized, and the professors spent a little too much time lecturing as opposed to facilitating discussion.
I can think of no weaknesses at this time

The only weakness I can call to mind would be that I wish we met for more than once a week. I felt that the ideas from the readings became far more clear once we began discussing them so another opportunity to do so would have been great. There were also many valuable perspectives and ideas that we mentioned in class alone so there would have likely been some more of this with more class time. Other than that, class ran smoothly with creative, meaningful activities and assignments. Grading was always fair and feedback was quick and useful. The greatest strength of this course was how we were never given any answers, but encouraged to look at the information provided to us, stop working, and start thinking about the proper way to tackle our challenges.

Strengths - course culminates nicely into forming a decent research proposal assuming no prior experience, ideally allowing you to conduct it someday. Two professors gives a second set of eyes to everything. Expectations laid out clearly for each assignment. Hands-on work in observing and measuring behavior with video, telemetry. Work is fairly consistent with 2-3 hours of reading with assignments getting weightier as the semester progresses.

Weaknesses - somewhat misleading course description since essentially the class is dedicated to forming a research proposal regarding owl monkeys at the Argentine Chaco, starting from actually how to observe and measure behavior but then turning essentially into a research tutorial course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Being in person, everything was essentially normal except we had to wear masks
This class was in person. Seeing my peers in person every week can not be beat by any online teaching. I am thankful that the professors decided to hold this class in person.

We were fortunate enough to meet in person after the quarantine was over, so that was a welcome change to my schedule. That being said, for the online portion of the class, the professors handled everything quite well. Discussions still flowed nicely and all information came across fine.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This course was so wonderful, and Professors Valeggia and Fernandez-Duque are some of the kindest professors I have had. They create a learning environment that is easy and exciting to engage in.
Yes, I would recommend this course. If you are planning to pursue a career in science this class is extremely beneficial.

To any student planning on doing any type of scientific research I beg of you to take this course. The course questions the mainstream habits of those applying the scientific method and ensures that you are not making the same errors. Beyond this, the course offers valuable practice and points to consider while writing a research proposal along with excellent feedback. For those who are considering wildlife behavioral studies or field studies in general, the methods the class covers can be applied to any organism or environment and introduces students to an interesting ecosystem.

If you want a specific research proposal to carry out in the future, definitely. If you want an introduction to writing your first research proposal and using those skills in other projects, sure. If you want a class solely on how scientists observe and measure behavior, you are in for a lot more.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live zoom for anyone in contact quarantine
